review, the “structure–mechanism” correlation has been established and the ordering behaviors of
BTA-containing derivatives were placed on the so-called cooperativity scale [
the signatures of self-assembly is the second aimof this study.
The remainder of this article is dividedinto three sections. The next chapter contains the discussion
of the results and consists of three sub-chapters: The binding energy diagrams calculated for the
azo–BTA dimers are discussed ﬁrst, followed by the Hirshfeld surface analysis of the crystalline
azo–BTA star phase found in the literature [
], and then concluded by the quantiﬁcation of the
signatures of cooperative growth of the star-shape azobenzenes stacks. This section is followed by
conclusions and how the results can be interpreted in the perspective of previous studies and of the
working hypotheses. Lastly, we give an overview of the models and computer simulation techniques
We begin the description of the results with a discussion of the dimers made of azo–BTA stars
a). The orientation of the molecules in dimers is parallel, and hence their structure can be
quantiﬁed by their segregation meaning that they are placed one above another. The binding energy
) for the molecular dimers and the assemblies of larger
is the energy of the column of size
monomer, i.e., the azo–BTA star. More details can be found in Section
The varied parameter for calculation of the binding strength is the distance
of the BTA cores, as schematically shown in Figure
distances. The task here is to
determine the most energetically favorable distance between the star cores in the column. This task
sounds rather trivial, but on one side, the knowledge of this distance is necessary for subsequent
simulations, and on another side, the experimental benchmarking using data fromthe literature allows
us to learn about the accuracy of the computer-based research methods.
The analysis of the experimental data [
] on the ordered phases of various BTA–cored
three-armed stars reveals that the intermolecular separations in the stacks range from 3.51 to 3.89
for the molecules with different periphery around the star center. Apparently, there is no clear
and the bulkiness of the star arms. For example, for almost the same
stacking separations are nearly equal to 3.6
and longer/bulkier arms (linear and branched C
The reason may lie in the many possibilities the molecules can be assembled in the ordered phases:
The stars can build segregated columns, be rotated around the core in the star plane or shifted laterally
We would like to stress here that the values found in experimental investigations of similar
compounds belong to the range of negative binding strengths. The strongest coupling between
